[This game does not use adventure-style commands. Enter a single word, or a single phrase -- the direction you want to go, or the object you want to examine, or the answer you want to give.]




>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Void: The Center
Void
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(directions: 
literal
, 
structure
, 
shape
, 
essence
)
Welcome to the 
Fifth Praser Maze,
 a product of Sadistic Software (on the Beat-Your-Nose Tour.) The Maze was designed, written, ported to the Web, and then ported again to Z-code by Andrew Plotkin 
<erkyrath@eblong.com>
.


The Rules:



Wander around. Puzzles will be posed. Eventually you win.


Philosophy:



Some games make their puzzles too dense, by packing too many puzzles into the same sets of clues. Some make theirs too sparse, by putting in too many red herrings. I have tried to achieve a balance, by doing both.


Playing the Game:



Type one of the highlighted words to go in a direction, examine an object, or talk to a creature. You do not need to use Adventure-style commands like "take sword" or "read parchment". A single word will work.

Type a creature's name to begin speaking to it. (Merely naming its species is rarely sufficient!) Creatures often ask questions, or pose riddles. When you are speaking to a creature, you will see a double ">>" prompt. You can then type a word or phrase to try to answer the riddle. If you are correct, you will be rewarded.

(You can still move in directions, and examine objects, at the ">>" prompt.)


Special commands:



void
 will always return you to the starting location.

look
 or 
l
: look at the location again.

about
 and 
credits
: show this message, and the game's credits.

save
 and 
restore
: save your position to a file, and restore it.

quit
 or 
q
: end the game.



Free hint:



Don't make assumptions about what you're being asked.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Void: The Center
Void
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(directions: 
literal
, 
structure
, 
shape
, 
essence
)
I'm afraid I don't know how to do that.




>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Void: The Center
Void
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
(directions: 
literal
, 
structure
, 
shape
, 
essence
)
[This game does not use adventure-style commands. Enter a single word, or a single phrase -- the direction you want to go, or the object you want to examine, or the answer you want to give.]




>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Void: The Center

literal
, 
structure
, 
shape
, 
essence
)
Are you sure you want to quit? 

=== promoted.z5 (v5) ===
     The e-mail has a surprising tone for a declaration of doom.



--------------------

From: Your Boss!

To: You

CC: Everyone



     Congratualtions!  Due to attrition among the ranks of middle managers, you have been promoted to management as of right now.  Have someone move your telephone and computer to your new office in the management section, and call me before the end of the day.



--------------------



     There is no reason to ask for whom the bell tolls, it tolls for you.  First, that message went to everyone, announcing that you have been promoted.  As soon as your back is turned it will be so full of daggers you could open a cutlery shop.  On top of that, your phone has been broken for months.



     You tried begging, bribery, even threats.  You just can not get a new phone.  Now, you have to move to the new office, with a new phone, before the end of the day.  If you don't, you won't lose the promotion, you will lose your job.  Most new managers become sacrificial scapegoats for the board of directors on their first day.



     You will just have to be smarter than those other fledgling managers.  If you have problems, you can always resort to "Big D's Guide to Corporate Survival" (ie. the walkthrough).  You keep it in your desk drawer.



    Well, there is work to be done.  Get that phone and get your equipment to the new office.

About this game


Promoted! Copyright 1996 by Mike DeSanto


a game for Rexx-Adventure, submitted to the Second Annual Interactive Fiction Authoring Competition.


This game is public domain.  Feel free to distribute, copy, plagiarize from.


Z-machine port (Release 1.1) by J. Steingraeber 1997, compiled with Linux Inform 6.05


Special thanks to Mike DeSanto, who very patient answered all my questions about Rexx-Adventure!


For menu-navigation use the cursor keys or


               '8' for cursor up,

                         |

 '4' for cursor left,  --+--  '6' for cursor right,

                         |

               '2' for cursor down.


Use 'Return' to select an entry.

Use 'Backspace' or 'Esc' or '9' to cancel a menu.


The number of menu lines can be changed in the System Commands.

=== puerto.z5 (v5) ===

Welcome to Puerto Rico

Inform adaptation by J. Robinson Wheeler. Play testing by Storme Winfield.

Release 1.1 / Serial number 20050101 / Inform v6.21


Type HELP at any prompt for full list of game commands (recommended)

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.


How many players? (2-5) >

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.


How many players? (2-5) >

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.


How many players? (2-5) >

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.


How many players? (2-5) >

Please choose a number between 2 and 5.


How many players? (2-5) >

Commands at any prompt:

  x [Role]    -  Print stats relevant to Role card (Mayor, Settler, etc)

  x [bldg]    -  Print Building tile info (sMkt, Haci, CtyH, etc)

  p[num]      -  Print Player data (p1, p2, ... p5)

  0           -  Cancel or pass turn, when applicable

  quit        -  Quit game

  ?, help     -  This menu


Type "pr1" or "pr2" to choose Prospector1 or Prospector2 cards during Role selection.


Type "printvp" to toggle printing of accumulated VP tokens when viewing Player data. (Default is OFF.)

=== punkpnts.z5 (v5) ===





At the Show


You're in a dark, poorly lit and packed club. Everyone's staring at the band as they go about tuning and shifting their instruments. The guy next to you has a mohawk that flops over to the side, as if the heat had wilted it. In contrast, the skinhead in front of you is reacting to the heat like a Mexican jumping bean, the muscles of his back tensing and releasing, tensing and releasing.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.

0

1
That's not a verb I recognise.

At the Show
Score:

Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
That's not a verb I recognise.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the Show
Score: 
0
Moves: 
1
Before you can do anything, the band explodes into action. The crowd coalesces into a single entity and leans towards them, falls back, ripples spastically. Being part of this lurching creature makes your spine tingle.

You're pressed from all sides by people suddenly activated by sound -- but you can't hear anything. You can practically feel the sonic waves, see it on the faces of the people around you... You strain to hear the music... 

The guy with the mohawk plants his boot in the skinhead's linked hands. His pierced nostrils flaring, hands gripping the skinhead's shoulders, he launches himself on the crowd. Improbably, they hold him aloft as he rolls over a bed made of their shoulders, heads and outstretched hands. You can't quite believe what you're seeing, and suddenly you hear something:

"Honey?"

You whip around and look to see who spoke, but there's nothing except the unremarkable brick wall of the club lined with people standing on chairs to get a better view. None of them are looking at you.

You look back. The guy with the mohawk is still rolling over the crowd, but for some reason he's got a tie on. And his blue hair is flickering like flames. The skinhead offers his linked hands to boost you up, and you quickly put your foot in. But your foot is bare. He looks at you, his dark eyes questioning. You realize with dawning horror that it isn't just your foot that's bare -- you're  in your underwear. You feel, rather than see, the eyes of the people in the crowd move towards you, brace yourself for the mocking laughter sure to ensue... 

"Honey! Get up!"

You're in your bed.

Your mother bustles in with your uniform, freshly ironed, and hangs it on your bathroom doorknob. "OK, honey, we're off," she says, stopping at the foot of your bed and putting her hands on her hips. "Better hurry or you'll miss your bus. Don't want to be late for the very first day of high school!"

You smile weakly as she kisses you goodbye and leaves, trying to rekindle the feelings in your dream.



Your Room
 (on 
the 
bed
)


Your room is a mess -- posters slowly peel off the walls to join the small heaps of clothes that spot the floor like death mounds. There's a path south through the junk from your bed to your bathroom, one going north to the rest of the house.



You
 can 
see 
a 
school uniform
 here.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Room
Score: 
0
Moves: 
2
Have you EXAMINED everything around you? Have you checked to see what you have in your INVENTORY recently? If you're trying to get useful things out of characters, ASK ____ ABOUT ____ will be the most revealing. Keep in mind that 80% of the commands needed to win the game are in the format VERB NOUN (ie. ATTACK STU). If you'd like to see how far into the game you are, check your SCORE, and you can UNDO one turn. There's also INFO on the game itself.

And that's all the help you get. Hints are for fucking posers.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Room
Score: 
0
Moves: 
3
You'll have to get 
off 
the 
bed
 first.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Room
Score: 
0
Moves: 
4
school uniform
: 
You can't reach it from your bed.


clothes
: 
Even if you didn't need to get into uniform, they're dirty.


posters
: 
Not exactly essential for your first day at school.


bed
: 
Don't bother with that.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Your Room

0

Are you sure you want to quit?

=== pytho.z8 (v8) ===




A small room.  Three men; you recognize only one.

"You, Soteria," says the leader.  "I understand you have an invitation to the Celebration of the Night of the Comet."

Heat floods your face.  How does he know that?  "I have an invitation, but I wasn't sure-- that is, I wasn't planning--"

"You'll go," he says.

The words die half-formed.  An urgent command overrides your personal doubts.

"What am I to do?"

"Speak to the Physician -- he's one of ours, but we've been unable to speak to him of late.  Find out anything he knows about the King's illness.  And protect the King."

"From what?"

The leader smiles a little wryly.  "I wish I could tell you, girl.  This is the Night of the Comet.  It could be anything."



                    [ Hit RETURN to continue... ]


As you turn to go, one of the others touches your arm.  "How did you get an invitation? We've all been trying for months--"

"Someone gave it to me," you say curtly.  "A rendezvous of sorts."

"But--"

"Don't worry, I'll attend to my duty," you say.  Adding, mostly to yourself: "The masked man won't be there anyway, I'm sure."  Since he became an outlaw shortly after he invited you...




Pytho's Mask

Copyright (c) 2001 by Emily Short.  (First-time users should type 'help'.)

Release 
3
 / Serial number 
0
2
0
2
2
3
 / Inform v
6
.
1
5
 Library 
6/10
 




Terrace


A terrace of lunar marble, surrounded by a low balustrade.  It gleams softly of its own in the darkening night.

To the west, shallow steps descend to the enclosure of the Square Garden; east beckons the brilliance of the Sun Court.




The minister of the moon stands at the far end, gazing upwards.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
No conversation
Terrace
That's not a verb I recognize.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
No conversation
Terrace
That's not a verb I recognize.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
No conversation
Terrace
That's not a verb I recognize.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
No conversation
Terrace
That's not a verb I recognize.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
No conversation
Terrace
Ordinarily you do not bother, but tonight... tonight you let your mother's own maid work her full magic.  You look magnificent, all emeralds and silk and high-piled hair, so that you startle yourself every time you catch a reflection in one of the gilded mirrors.




"A fine night," the Moon Minister comments, though he barely turns to acknowledge your presence.  "The viewing is good.  When the comet rises it will be clearer than the moon itself."



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Talking to: 
Moon Minister
Terrace
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A: 
"Have you seen the comet before?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
B: 
"How often does the comet appear?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At any time you can see from the status bar to whom you are talking; sometimes there is also a list of up to four comments that you can make.  Choose one of these by typing >A, >B, >C, etc. at the prompt, just as you would any other verb.

If you are dissatisfied with the selection, you can also type >TOPIC <SOMETHING>.  So for instance if your options listed at the moment are all vapid remarks about fashion and you would rather say, "Pass 
the Stilton, please," you might try >TOPIC CHEESE.  >TOPIC does not cost a turn to use, so you can explore a number of topics if you're looking for something specific to say.  For your convenience this is also abbreviated to >T.  So >T CHEESE would work, too.

To talk to a new person, type >GREET <PERSON>; to say goodbye try >T GOODBYE.  To revert to the topic you were on at the end of the last conversational exchange, >UNTOPIC.

For a list of all the characters you have encountered so far, >PERSONAE (or just >P).

See also CREDITS.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Talking to: 
Moon Minister
Terrace
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A: 
"Have you seen the comet before?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
B: 
"How often does the comet appear?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
You can go only 
east
 or 
west
.



>

Moon Minister
Terrace
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A: 
"Have you seen the comet before?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
B: 
"How often does the comet appear?"


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
comet
: 
You can't reach 
the 
comet
 from here.


sky
:

the 
sky
 from here.


balustrade
: 
That's 
hardly portable.



>

Coffee House


The book on the round, maroon table is looking at you. In this sunny May afternoon, you wanted to read the book and be outside also. So you took it and came to this coffee house. You are wondering what the protagonist will do next.

You glance at the people who are in light colored clothes and look somewhat dizzy from the lightly blowing wind. The umbrella over you provides an ideal dimness. From the speaker near the entrance of the inner caf, a woman is singing an ultimately boring French song.

Thus, everything is so suitable to read.

The final round is about to begin. Get out there and win!

=== residnt2.z5 (v5) ===
          The Resident



  'You just visit the WEB, I live here.'



  Copyright 1995 by Mike DeSanto



  You are awake.  The clock says it is 2: 30 AM, so thee must be a reason you are awake.  Trusting your instincts, you get the Beretta handlaser from the end table.



  You move silently toward the bedroom door.  There are people who hate you, but most of them don't know who you are, and you just moved in here.  A change of residence and name come with every completed job.  There have been no hitches or displeased customers lately.



  Just as you reach for the door these thoughts are shattered.  The door disappears in a blinding, searing light.  Through the agony you feel the dresser opposite the door hit you in the small of the back, a trivial pain to the fire in the front of your body.



  Then something else starts.  A pushing feeling starting at your right hip.  It continues diagonally to your left shoulder, leaving sharp points of suffering, like ten thousand bee stings across your body.  You feel yourself falling, but never feel the floor.



  With a start, you are awake.  Looking around, you see the red traceries and yellow disks of the WEB stretching out all around you.  you must have fallen asleep on line again.



  Your left arm itches, you must be laying on it.  You reach for the LOGOUT button, and find nothing.  The logout is gone.  Looking around a little more, everything is gone!  Your programs, even your Icon!  You spent hours on that icon.  Getting just the right amount of five o'clock shadow, just the right tackiness to the slippers.  It was a masterpiece!



  Just as you are starting to get nervous, a message appears on your deck.  Strange dreams just before strange messages make you unhappy.  At least you have your backups at Bob's.



    You are standing in a standard Public node.  The 'ground' is a neon yellow disk, large enough for everyone present to fit, no matter how many people are here.



    In the center of the disk is a red pole with arrow shaped signs.  This is the transfer point to all connected nodes.



    Next to the Transfer Point is a large sign which reads "INFORMATION" in tall block capitals.  You can not read the rest without looking more closely.



    As usual, there are hundreds of people moving through this node.  Since this is where everyone starts when they log in, it tends to be a busy place.





GATEWAY-PUB

>

> 
About
.


This is the Z-machine port of a game originally written for Rexx-Adventure. Rexx-Adventure is a point-and-click interface for textadventures designed by Mike DeSanto. To cite the Rexx-Adventure documentation:


        "Rexx-Adventure is a text adventure engine for OS/2.  The fact that it is an engine means that it is not a set, single adventure.  It is a framework for writing new adventures."


And about gameplay it says:


        "To use an object, click on it.  This will display a list of appropriate actions for that object.  Simply choose the action you wish to perform.  In some cases, an indirect object will be necessary.  In this case, the indirect object window will appear, and you choose one from the list.  The results of your action will be displayed in the text window."


This version of the game simulates Rexx-Adventure by using menus.


Z-machine port by J. Steingraeber 1997, compiled with Linux Inform 6.13


For menu-navigation use the cursor keys or


               '8' for cursor up,

                         |

 '4' for cursor left,  --+--  '6' for cursor right,

                         |

               '2' for cursor down.


Use 'Return' to select an entry.

Use 'Backspace' or 'Esc' or '9' to cancel a menu.


The number of menu lines can be changed in the System Commands.

Message - C
.


 To:    The Resident

 From:  Ringer

 Subject:  Welcome back.



    Greetings, Resident.  I am known as Ringer, and I am your new employer.  The doctors say you may be confused by the trauma you have suffered, so I will go over the events of the last few days.



    Three days ago, a very nearly successful attempt was made on your life.  An assassin used a shaped explosive to enter your room, and used a flechette rifle to saw you in half from shoulder to hip.



    Luckily, the police and ambulance arrived very quickly, and you were taken to a hospital.  Once there, you were placed on life support while your credit rating was checked.  On my instructions, you were declared dead and brought to a private hospital, where you were implanted with a full nervous link.  All of your senses are fed by the WEB at this point.  To disconnect you from the WEB would leave you in a world here there is only pain, and you would quickly go mad.



    They say that you are called the Resident because you spend more time in the WEB than out of it.  I find it ironic that your name is now more true than ever.  If you perform the tasks I give you satisfactorily, I will have you fitted with cybernetics to replace the limbs and organs that you lost, or with a Clone body, your choice.



    Before you start getting ideas, I did not have you attacked. I do not know who did or why.  I was planning to hire you anyway, because your name is well known on the WEB.  I have some work for you to do.  When you are not busy with my tasks, feel free to track down your assassin.  When you find the who ordered the hit, I will deal with them for you.



    As for your first task, I need to gain entry into Geneva Materials Science Corporation.  You must infiltrate their computer system and sabotage the security systems to let me and my strike team into the building.  Any necessary information about the team will be provide when you are in the system.



    You will receive more instructions when you need them.  Work quickly to finish this task, and good luck finding your attacker.



 The Ringer

=== reverb.z5 (v5) ===


Life sucks. Today has been just another crummy day in another dismal spring which you've spent delivering pizzas. This afternoon has totally been dragging, except for that bit of excitement an hour ago when you broke the soda machine. You thought your boss was going to rip you a new orifice.

Anyway, you've just finished mopping up behind the counter. There's only one more hour left on your shift and you're anxious to get out of here. Go home, watch the tube, blast some tunes, maybe scan the new "Surfers Monthly" magazine... gonna be a nice relaxing evening.

Shyeah, right. That's what YOU think.



REVERBERATIONS

A Hectic Voltairian Adventure
Copyright (c) 1996 by Russell Glasser.
Updated and revised 1998

There is something pressing that you think you have to do, but you can't think what it might be.

=== reverzi.z5 (v5) ===

[Spc] Enter move

Fast

?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Invalid move]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Invalid move]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Invalid move]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Invalid move]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Invalid move]
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Rules:


Black (X) moves first.

To make a legal move, your piece must be placed next to a piece of the opposite color. The move is legal if somewhere on the column/row/diagonal in the direction of the opposite piece is one of your own pieces. All opposite pieces in this direction are then captured by you and will change to your color.

If your piece is placed next to several pieces of the opposite color then you capture those pieces also.

If you have no possible moves you will be forced to pass your turn. To manually pass simply press "P". Two consecutive passes (one by you and one by the computer will end the game.

If the computer cannot make a move it will display a message. You continue to make your moves as normal.

The game is over when all fields are occupied or when no side can make a legal move. The winner of the game is the one with the most pieces when the game is over.


Controls: Use the arrow keys to move the cursor (the "?") around the board. When the "?" is where you want to place your piece, press the space bar. You can also use the "W", "A", "S" and "Z" keys to move the cursor.

Most of the menu choices should be self-explanatory. "C" allows you to change sides. Press "P" to pass, "Q" to quit and "H" to diplay this information. "M" changes the game's mode between fast and slow. In "slow" mode, the game will pause after you make a move, so that you can see the results of your move. In "fast" mode, the computer will make it's move immediately after you make yours, then display the results.


?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Play again? (y/n) 

=== ribbons.z5 (v5) ===






Ribbons


An IF Art Show 2001 Still Life

by J.D. Berry (berryx@earthlink.net)
(Type 'about' at any > prompt for a freeware disclaimer.  An 'overview' is recommended if this is your first time playing.  A mildly 'amusing' command is available if the mood strikes.)

*A bias lurks.


Release 
2
 / Serial number 
0
1
0
7
0
2
 / Inform v
6
.
2
1
 Library 
6/10
 




Train


A model train display covers a 4' x 8' pool table.  Taped to the right corner of the table, a yellow ribbon hangs.  The lighting is hazy.

[Other perspectives:  Right, Left, Far]




>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Nobody recognizes that verb, anymore.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Some people find you attractive.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
In brief:

A "text model" requires examination.  But while examining something does not necessarily imply just looking at it, the command "examine" (or simply "x") usually does.  The e(x)amine, listen, touch and smell commands are implemented on most objects.  Taste is pretty much frowned upon.

"x display" will get you started at each perspective.  To move to a perspective you can type its relative position or its name.

Generally etiquette will forbid you from attempting a lot of standard "adventuring" things.  You should be able to discern when and where you can perform these actions (e.g. move, press).  But don't be afraid to try something, if nothing else for the humor potential (key word:  "potential".)

Score is available as a vague indicator of how much you've experienced.  Type exit to leave the game.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
Type 'exit' to end your session.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train
There are none at all available!



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train

End this viewing of "Ribbons"? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Train

A nostalgic diversion by Torbjrn Andersson

"You can't miss it," they said. "A white house in a clearing with a small mailbox outside; just open the kitchen window and the entrance to the Great Underground Empire isn't far away."


You found the house and the window all right, and a trapdoor leading down. But as the trapdoor crashed shut behind you, you realized that something was very wrong. Surely the GUE shouldn't look like a large square room with bare walls, and what about those menacing shapes advancing towards you...?

Direct bug reports, flames, or even positive feedback to shanos@es.co.nz.


This is a port of the rogue 5.3-
clone
 code.  
If you're used to the original or the PC version, expect to 
encounter some small differences.


Concise help can be viewed during the game by pressing "?".  Pressing it twice 
will put the game into a menu of help topics which are hopefully a little 
more... helpful.


For a list of changes in recent releases, read the "News" help topic.  
Don't forget -- it's good for your soul.

=== samhain.z5 (v5) ===




You feel like such a whore. 

First they washed you.  They rubbed your skin with a soft cloth, made you clean and gleaming.  Then they painted you a face, a cute little 'hello, sailor' smirk.  After examining your weight, luster and overall beauty, they determined your price. 

Then they put you out with the others, to wait for passers-by. 



Samhain: A Second-Person Slash 'Em-Up

(or, Pick Up The Jack O' Lantern And Die) 
(Special Edition, Director's Cut, With Commentary and Deleted Scenes) 
An Eddie Mueller Production, Copyright 2000 
(Type ABOUT for credits/special commands)

=== scald.z5 (v5) ===


SCALD.Z5

Copyright (c) 2018 by John Baptist

Release 
1
 / Serial number 
1
8
0
2
0
6
 / Inform v
6
.
3
3
 Library 
6/11
 
S




Bedroom
 (on 
the 
bed
)


When the springy energy of muscle long ago gave way to a slothful paunch, you didn't mind. You simply redirected your energies from the libertine idylls of youth to the ruthless game of business, and in that you succeeded admirably. You built Splinecorp from the humble beginnings of your parents' garage into the world's most prominent manufacturer of electronic goods. You invested your whole adult life into the company, and it paid you back handsomely, you sometimes consider as you relax in your sprawling, isolated mansion. But age takes its toll. Even your healthy middle-aged paunch began to dissolve, what remained of your muscles were consumed by sluggish board meetings, and innumerable diseases began to gnaw at you from the inside out. Your increasing frailty has confined you to this bed for the last five years, but your mind, of course, is as sharp as ever and you have no intent of relinquishing your place on the Splinecorp executive board. Fortunately, here in your linen prison, you've provided yourself with the tools to look after yourself: the rack of monitors hanging from ceiling keeps you informed, and of course your faithful Splinecorp-manufactured robots stand by, waiting your command. Hanging on the eastern wall is an ornate tapestry. And standing next to your bed is a comprehensive array of tubes, drips, and associated medical machines, and also a small nightstand. To the south is a doorway to the hallway.


The phone starts ringing.



You
 can 
see 
Levo
 and 
Pravo
 here.

Bedroom
 (on 
the 
bed

This spacious room serves as your bedroom, your hospital, your jail. Your enormous, elaborate bed occupies the bulk of the space here. Next to the bed is an array of medical devices, several are which are plugged directly into your body. Also next to the bed is a nightstand. Hanging on the eastern wall is an ornate tapestry, and the northern wall is dominated by a window from which you could see your garden, if it weren't dark outside. Suspended from the ceiling is a metal rack holding several monitors, your links to the outside world. To the south is a doorway to the hallway.

=== schooldays.z5 (v5) ===






 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
School Days: Prologue




You have recently lived in Toronto but then your parents moved away. You really loved them. But, you were kidnapped and locked in this house. Those kidnappers really should be put in jail.

Well, you don't want to stay here any longer than you can help. You want to get to school on this Saturday to see your grade nine pals. And last night you were shoved in this house. As you wake up, you realise...


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
[Please press any key to begin.]





... that you are all alone in a locked bedroom, and you need to find a way out.



Schooldays Version 
3
 is Copyright (c) 2000 Andrew MacKinnon.
New users might want to type 'help'.



Bedroom


This bedroom is a medium-sized room, with an ugly flower wallpaper. A dresser sits in an awkward corner. An entrance to a small bathroom is to the west while the door to the main corridor to the east. A cheap window sits at one side. A trapdoor in the ceiling seems to lead up to an attic, although high up.




The door to the hallway is currently closed.




The trapdoor is closed, blocking the way into the attic.



A mahogany double dresser sits here. 
In the dresser, 
there are no open drawers.

also

sheets

=== seacoral.z5 (v5) ===




You have just entered the stern airlock aboard the MV Pollux. You have been diving the coral reefs around the middle keys while the Pollux has been patrolling the Florida Straits near the southern end of Florida.


You can enter [Help] at the start for help relevant to this game, then [About] and [Credits] for additional information.

In general you will be able to converse with the non player chaaracters [NPCs] within this adventure. Just enter [Talk] to [NPC].

Note: When within the [Talk] menu, just select the number '1'. Pressing enter drops you out of the talk menu. You can get back to the talk menu by entering [Talk] to [NPC] again. It is generally best to choose the option in the #1 position as you converse, but it is not required.



Sea Coral

A deep sea adventure for Punyjam #3.


Release 
1
 / Serial number

Airlock


The airlock is just big enough to accommodate you and Bart. It is a pressure equalization port below the water line that allows divers safe entry into the ship.

The main passageway is forward (Fore).

You are a US Navy SEAL on detachment to the US Coast Guard. You are working aboard the MV Pollux as a special agent policing US coastal territory to interdict drug trafficking, human smuggling, pirating and poaching.




> 
 
Airlock
          

          

          

          

          

      

 Moves: 
1
Conversations are not as complex as in Infocom titles. It is sufficient to type [Talk to NPC].

While onboard various marine vessels you can navigate using the nautical terms: [Fore], [Aft], [Port], [Starboard].

You may have to operate computers in this game.  The TAC computers have an advanced AI system. You can [Talk] to them for information. For additional information, Enter [About} and/or [Credits].

Use the [Save] command to store your progress and [Restore] to load it again.




> 
 
Airlock
          

          

          

          

          

      

 Moves: 
2
Main Passageway


The main passageway provides access to all areas of the Pollux.


At this point you need to investigate the environmental damage to the reef with something more capable than scuba diving.

The Deep Sea Submerssible Vehicle (DSRV) down in the Moon Pool.

=== selection.z5 (v5) ===


The Director's office surprises you. You had expected something modern with clean lines, and plenty of glass and aluminium; not this dark and cluttered room, reminiscent of a Victorian library or some ancient professor's study. Also, you had expected that you were being shown in for an interview with the Director, in person, whereas there is clearly no-one else here in this office. 


Final Selection

An Interactive Text Adventure
Copyright (c) 2006 by Sam Gordon.

Bug reports and other comments to sam_r_gordon@hotmail.com

This game makes use of the library scenic.h (by Richard Barnett, Joe Mason, Roger Firth and Stefano Gaburri).


Release 
3
 / Serial number 
0
6
1
0
0
9
 / Inform v
6
.
3
0
 Library 
6/11
 
S



Type HELP at any command prompt for help with using this game (but no hints about the puzzles).


Press any key to begin the game.


The Director's assistant follows you into the room. 

"As I told you, the Board of Trustees were impressed with your interview and they fully understand from your application why you see this as your perfect job. However, you failed to convince them on a single point: if you wish to become the new Director of the Museum and Institute for Puzzles and Problem Solving, they would like some evidence of your interest in solving problems. The retiring Director has been asked to assess you on that single point and, rather than interview you, he has set you an unusual test." 

With that, the assistant hands you a manilla envelope, then continues. 

"I am instructed to give you this envelope. Please read it and act on its contents. When you are ready to meet the Director, please ring the bell on his desk and I shall bring him in. He will ask you a single question. If you answer correctly, the job is yours: answer incorrectly and we shall have to look for a new candidate." 

The assistant moves briskly out of the room, wishing you a cheery "Good luck!" before shutting the door behind him. You hear the sound of a key being turned in the lock.





Office of the Director


This room reminds you of a Victorian study: it is roughly square and all the exposed walls are panelled with dark oak, up to a height of about six feet, with bare cream plaster above. In the centre of the room is an old mahogany desk, with a leather chair behind it. Beyond the desk is a stone fireplace, with a framed painting above it. One of the side walls is completely taken up with a book case, most of which is closed with glass doors. On the opposite wall, above a wooden table, is the only window, and sole source of light in this rather gloomy room. In the fourth wall is the single door. There is a clutter of miscellaneous items everywhere, and in the four corners of the room, you can see a hatstand, an antique globe, a wooden corner shelf and a low cupboard. 


At present you are standing beside the Director's desk, in the middle of the room.

the

You seem to be wearing your best interview clothes.



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Office of the Director
Moves: 
1
If you are not familiar with interactive fiction, some useful commands are:

* INVENTORY or INV or I to list what you are holding
* GET <object> or TAKE <object> to pick things up, and DROP <object> to drop them
* LOOK to get a general description of the room
* EXAMINE <object> or X <object> to take a close look at something
* PUT <object> ON (or IN) <object>
* OPEN <object> or CLOSE <object> if you would expect it to be openable.

The puzzle to be solved in this game involves some numbers and words. To save the player from having to record every possible clue on a piece of paper, all potentially relevant (and potentially irrelevant!) numbers, letters and words are noted for you and can be reviewed by typing NOTE or REVIEW, at any command prompt.

This game takes place entirely in one room, so the compass directions which are widely used in interactive fiction have no relevance to this game.

Although the location is a single room, the player's focus of attention is directed on one part of it at a time. This means that some commands will behave slightly differently, depending on the current focus. For instance, if the player is sitting at the desk, the LOOK command will give more detail about objects which are on the desk. Similarly, if the player is at the desk and types a command such as TAKE BOOK, the game will assume that this refers to the book on the desk (if there is one) rather than the one on, say, the bookcase. If you actually want the one on the bookcase, make it clear that this is the one you are referring to by typing TAKE RED BOOK, for instance, (if it is red). Doing so will not only allow you to take the book, but will automatically switch the focus to the part of the room where it is located. This is all less complicated than it sounds, and avoids the alternative of the game continually asking you to clarify which of several similar objects you are referring to.

Another unusual feature of the game is that, because the game takes place in a single location, there is little point in collecting every portable object into a huge inventory. The player doesn't have a "sack" and it would be unrealistic for the player to make a minute examination of a small scrap of paper whilst carrying armfuls of boxes, bags and clothing. Hence, quite a lot of the larger objects are "automatically" put down by the player, when attention switches to a new object. This should not be an inconvenience, as the object remains accessible to the player at all times, anyway. If you lose track of where something is in the room, you can type WHERE IS THE BELL (or whatever you are looking for) and you will normally be told the location of the item.

Nothing in the game can inflict a fatal injury on the player and it should not be possible to manipulate the objects so as to make the game unwinnable, until the very end. 

I hope you enjoy the game!



>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Office of the Director
Moves: 
2
The compass directions aren't relevant: firstly, there is only one exit (which is locked!) and, secondly, you don't have a compass. Although you can distinguish up and down, without a compass, there are no exits in those directions, either.

Well, now that my girlfriend's mad at me, where were we? Ah, right.


It's kind of boring here. I hear the king hasn't put anybody in the dungeon in over a year. Must make you feel special. It's drafty, being up in the tower, and the stones in the wall have chips and various--- do you really care? They're old. The door looks pretty sturdy. There's some light coming into the room from a window about, uh, twice your height up. Can we leave?

For more information about the game, use the commands below:
ABOUT CREDITS will list the game's credits.
ABOUT HINT will list the major puzzles in the game, if you find yourself unsure where to start looking.
ABOUT NOTES will display some notes on the structure of the game.
ABOUT VERBS will give you a list of verbs that might be useful.

To report bugs, tell us you love us, tell us you hate us, or otherwise comment on the game, you can reach us at speculative.fiction.if@gmail.com.

=== sgate.z5 (v5) ===


The last thing that you remember is standing before the wizard Lakmir as he waved his hands. Now you find yourself staring at an entryway which lies at the edge of a forest. The druid's words ring in your ears:

"Within the castle Shadowgate lies your quest. The dreaded Warlock Lord will use his black magic to raise the Behemoth from the dark depths. The combination of his evil arts and the great titan's power will surely destroy us all! You are the last of the line of kings, the seed of prophecy that was foretold eons ago. Only you can stop the evil one from darkening our world forever! Fare thee well."

Gritting your teeth, you swear by your god's name that you will destroy the Warlock Lord! 

[Press any key to begin.] 




SHADOWGATE

An unauthorized adaptation by David Griffith.
(Type "about" for more information. For a hint, type "hint".)

Release 
8
 / Serial number

Entrance


You are standing just south of the Castle Shadowgate. In front of you, to the north, is a heavy wooden door set in the stone wall of the castle. A skull hangs over the door.

THE CROWN vs DR. WATSON

Sherlock Holmes Solo Mysteries (#4)
by Gerald Lientz
Copyright (c) 1988 Iron Crown Enterprises.
Inform Adaptation by Doc

Release 
1
 / Serial number 
0

=== shade.z5 (v5) ===




    
*** SHADE ***

A brief story by "Ampe R. Sand" (Andrew Plotkin)
First-time players should type "about".

Release 
3
 / Serial number 
0
0
1
1
2
7
 / Inform v
6
.
2
1
 Library 
6/10
 




Odd, how the light just makes your apartment gloomier. Pre-dawn darkness pools in the corners and around the tops of walls. Your desk lamp glares yellow, but the shadows only draw your eyes and deepen.


Not much of an apartment, no.
 One desk, paper-piled, with a dusty computer shoved to the side.
 Your futon
.
 Second-hand stereo
 sitting on a cardboard crate
.
 A kitchen nook one way and a bathroom nook the other, with a closet to the side.
 A broad mirror tries to make the place seem twice its size; it halfway works.
 One window, whose shade is
 down
, and the front door
 firmly shut
.



Your luggage is piled untidily by the door.
 
A potted 
hyacinth
 sits beneath the window.



You are sprawled on the futon, staring up into that gloom. Your eyes feel gritty. But it's too late -- early -- no time left for sleep, anyway. In a few hours your ride will arrive.


On 
the 
desk
 are
 
your
 
to-do list
 and 
a 
travel book
.

This is a one-room game set in your apartment. ...But perhaps you've already gathered that.


SHADE mostly uses the standard vocabulary of interactive fiction. You may find the command "find..." (or "where is...") convenient, though not critically important.


SHADE is copyright 2000 by Andrew Plotkin (erkyrath@eblong.com). He began coding it on the morning of September 2, 2000, and raced like the wind to finish it in time for the Sixth Annual IF Competition. (SHADE placed tenth, which is pretty darn good, considering the overall excellence of the entries that year.) For more IF by the same author, see

    <http://www.eblong.com/zarf/if.html>

SHADE may be distributed for free, but not sold or included in any for-profit collection without written permission from the author.


All hail the beta-tester: Michael Kinyon (still inevitable after all these years). And the people who sent bug reports after the competition, who include (but are not limited to): Ross Presser, Gunther Schmidl, Matthew Murray, Joe Mason, Nick Wolfe, Caleb Wilson, Neil Cerutti, Jason McIntosh, Daryl McCullough, Lelah Conrad, Jeff Hall. And -- this game is dedicated to Meatball Fulton.

=== sherbet.z5 (v5) ===














 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The Meteor, The Stone And A Long Glass Of Sherbet 




 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
         [Please press SPACE to begin.]

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
I shall be telling this with a sigh
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Somewhere ages and ages hence:
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Two roads diverged in a wood, and I -
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
I took the one less travelled by,
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
And that has made all the difference.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
-- Robert Frost, "The Road Not Taken"
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 






Another day wasted as guest of the Empress, a wretchedly long tour of the breath-taking Boreal Falls, conducted as ever by the Lady Amilia. As if she weren't bad enough, an honour guard of soldiers, their breast-plates red in the setting sun, march ahead of the procession and protect you from seeing anything unrehearsed. It's a dog's life being an Ambassador.



The Meteor, the Stone and a Long Glass of Sherbet

The Interactive Memoirs of a Diplomat
Copyright (c) 1996 by Angela M. Horns
Winning entry in the 1996 Interactive Fiction Competition
(Please type "help" if you would like instructions.)

Release 
2
 / Serial number 
9
6
1
2
1
6
 / Inform v
6
.
1
0
 Library 
6/3


Standard interpreter 
1
.
2




Watling Street
 (
in
 
the 
cushioned basket
)


The ancient paved road stretches for miles to the south, turning very slowly to the northeast along a mossy stone wall. From up here on your elephant's wickerwork basket, you're just level with the branches of the old Imperial hunting woods inside the wall.

Having been stuck in this cushioned basket with the Lady Amilia every day for a fortnight, you're just desperate to get away.




The procession of elephants shuffles on, their enormous soles slapping onto the flagstones with a dull, regular boom.

Watling Street

in
 
the 
cushioned basket
)


The ancient paved road stretches for miles to the south, turning very slowly to the northeast along a mossy stone wall. From up here on your elephant's wickerwork basket, you're just level with the branches of the old Imperial hunting woods inside the wall.

Having been stuck in this cushioned basket with the Lady Amilia every day for a fortnight, you're just desperate to get away.




The procession of elephants shuffles on, their enormous soles slapping onto the flagstones with a dull, regular boom.

=== shrapnel.z5 (v5) ===


You are standing west
*** You have died ***
of a white house with
*** You have died ***
a boarded front door.
*** You have died ***
shrapnel by adam cadre




West of the house


You are standing west of a white house with a boarded front door.


You blink. Boarded? You came all this way and the door is 
boarded?


Is this supposed to be some sort of game?



>
[That verb is not recognized.]



>
[That verb is not recognized.]



>
You are Bill Blake, co-founder of Whitman & Blake Dry Goods, one of the leading such outfits in all of Dixie. It was Whitman, your partner, who convinced you to come all the way out here to his estate tonight -- he'd been increasingly concerned that there might be trouble. Trouble from whom? God only knows. That mumbling milquetoast has been jumping at shadows lately.



>
[That verb is not recognized.]



>
You walk around to the north side of the house...


...but before you can take more than a few steps, a trio of frenzied attack dogs comes bursting out from behind the house and tears you to pieces.



 
 
 
*** You have died ***




Would you like to RESTART, RESTORE a saved game, or QUIT?
> 
r

=== six-gray-rats.z8 (v8) ===






"
Poh
! I'm short a hundred florins on rent money!"

Lorenzo snickers. "I'll give you a hundred to spend the night in Count Ruggino's house."

"I'll do it! Wait. Why Ruggino's?"

"He's a suicide. They say his house is haunted."

"Haunted? I don't believe in ghosts."




Six Gray Rats Crawl Up The Pillow


A Gothic Vignette
 by 
Boswell Cain


Release 
2
 / Serial number 
1
5

 / Inform 7 build 
6L38
 
(I6/v

 lib 
6/12N
) 




Courtyard


Count Ruggino's house lours in the dim air like a gathering of gravestones. The road makes a circle before it, then runs north back to Firenze.




A heavy wooden door leads in to the south.




A statue stands in the center of a dry fountain.

=== solitary.z5 (v5) ===






 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
I sate a long time upon a stone
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
at the margin of the lake, and after a
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
flood of tears my heart was easier.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
---Dorothy Wordsworth
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




         [->]

Classes finally ended, and you walk home through the nearly deserted campus. It's a Thursday, and you had night classes, so almost no one is around. Up a few flights of stairs, you slip the key into the lock, turn, and walk inside. Turning swiftly, you lock the door, and pick up your todo list. Still, you just don't feel like doing work. Your heart is heavy, and you feel you won't really be able to get anything done.




Solitary

A Single Room Reminiscence
Copyright (c) 2004 by Kahlan.

Release 
0
 / Serial number 
0
4
0
6
0
7
 / Inform v
6
.
3
0
 Library 
6/11
 
S




Dorm Room


This is your room, where you've have some of your most cherished moments. It's been just about half a year since the start of classes, but even in that short period, you've made many memories. Mornings are the most pleasant here, sunlight shines through the windows, casting the room in the golden hue of the dawn. Your desk is decorated with pictures, pencils, snacks, and books. The walls are sparse, mostly white, no posters or anything, you prefer it neat. Almost everything is ordered, and not a thing is usually out of place. Your bed is in one corner of the room. The windows are dark, it's night time out.




A nightstand is beside the desk, with a few frills on top.




A fair sized metal typewriter is on the desk.




Your writing notebook rests here, but it's unimportant to you.



>

...Flowers. James knows that I love flowers, especially roses. He works part time, just to buy me flowers. I know they are expensive, but... I love them too much to tell him that I know he works for them.


Your name is Amy, and you're an eighteen year old college freshman. This is your first year, and much of it has been hard for you. Events from last week have been especially bad. You're feeling sick, tired, depressed, and hardly motivated to do anything. You never were the type to wear too much jewelry or makeup, but recently, you haven't worn any at all, it just doesn't seem to be worth the effort.

Scooter

Time: 
3010
It's been ten years since your stationfall on Space Station Gamma Delta Gamma 777-G 59/59. Your heroics in saving the galaxy from the evil alien pyramid resulted in a big promotion, but your life of dull paperwork has been replaced by a life of dull people work: escorting ambassadors, high-ranking officers of the Stellar Patrol, and government officials; and inspecting starships and space stations. Today you find yourself in a space scooter bound for a space station to perform a spot check, and also deliver some radioactive isotopes for their reactor, using the scooter instead of the teleport in order to surprise everyone. You've been a bit delayed due to a diplomatic crisis on Omicron III and your scooter isn't equipped with communication equipment, so you are arriving unannounced. Hey, rank does have its privileges, and it is meant to be a spot check...



SPACE STATION

Inform interactive fiction -- a science fiction story
by David Ledgard and the Online Inform Community
Email: me@dmledgard.freeserve.co.uk
Planetfall (c) Activision, Inc. Permission to use courtesy of Activision, Inc.
Not for commercial distribution
Type HELP for help

This game is based on the example transcript included with Infocom's Planetfall game, by Steve Meretzky. All Infocom games are now the property of Activision. It understands the following commands:

North, South, East, West, Fore, Aft, Starboard, Port, Up, Down, In, Out, Exit, Examine, Look, Look through, Diagnose, Time, Score, Wait, Shake, Open, Cut, Close, Lock, Unlock, Take, Drop, Type, Push, Kick, Crush, Play, Sit, Stand, Read, Save, Restore, Restart, Quit, Brief, Superbrief, Verbose, Version, Again, Oops, Eat, Drink, Use, Break, Put, Make, Give <OBJECT> to <ACTOR>, Tell <ACTOR> about <SUBJECT>, Plug <OBJECT1> in <OBJECT2>, Show <OBJECT> to <ACTOR>, Unplug <OBJECT>, Footnote <NUMBER>, Wait <NUMBER>, Wake <ACTOR> ...

The game descriptions for this games use fore, aft, port, and starboard for directions which can be abbreviated to f, a, p, sb. If you are not comfortable using these directions you can still use respectively north, south, west, east which can be abbreviated to n, s, w, e. Up and Down work as usual. You can examine AND read books.

Some of the commands have to be combined with objects, carried by the player, or found in rooms. The maximum score is 
23
 at present. The puzzles aren't very complicated; just examine EVERYTHING, and you should be able to solve them. Good luck, and enjoy! And if you think Activision should resurrect Planetfall II, LET THEM KNOW.

There may be some spelling mistakes in this game, but probably not as many as you think. The spelling is British English, which is not exactly the same as American English (which I assume many players use). That's my story and I'm sticking to it.

When the program is run using WInfocom, the opening text may be a bit garbled; just type RESTART.

I would like to thank the following people for their help in this project:
David Dyte for organizing the 1998 Interactive Fiction Competition and Technical Advice while I was learning Inform. Everyone on the rec.arts.int-fiction newsgroup who gave me technical advice (too numerous to mention).
Version 1 Beta Testers: Vincent Lynch, Mary K. Kuhner, Stephen Robert Norris, Stuart Andrew Moore and Imran Ghory.
Version 2 Beta Testers: James Braun, Bronxelf (a former Infocom Tester who worked with Steve Meretzky), Tom Lorimer, Jason F. Finx (a star grammer checker), Chad Schultz and Mark Silcox.

You can Email the author at me@dmledgard.freeserve.co.uk with error reports, possible improvements etc...

Brother Joseph now speaks directly to the entire Order.

"Fellow Brothers, the year, as you know, is 976 GUE. A difficult time indeed. Ten years have passed since the Cataclysm brought forth by the Circle of Enchanters changed our world forever. The outside world as we know it is in turmoil. A period of great change is upon all of us."


>
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Monastery Chapel
Score: 
0
Moves: 
2
Hello Player!

SPIRITWRAK, An Interactive Fantasy Adventure
If you're new to interactive fiction games, I lack the space here to give an adequate description, but in short, you're a character in a story, able to interact with objects, places and other things (using regular english sentences) in order to reach your goal, which is to figure out how to "solve" the story. For a real description, you might want to check out documents located at ftp.gmd.de.

For those more experienced players, if you're looking for on-line clues, etc., sadly, you won't find them (the Z5 code is getting rather obscenely large as I write this). A short verb list is contained in the README file that you should have received with this game (or should be able to find at the same place you found this game). Beyond that, if you're truly desperate, you can post a note on the rec.arts.int-fiction usenet newsgroup, or send me email.

Thanks for playing! 

-- D. S. Yu [dsyu@holonet.net]

You are caught up in the collective chanting, and cannot break your concentration to do much of anything else.



Brother Joseph continues speaking.

"Our order has always maintained the strictest secrecy. Few outside of our order know of our existence. We are the keepers of the mystic balance that which embodies pure magic that can keep our world safe. It has always been thus -- we watch over all of Quendor, never interfering in the affairs of others, yet striving to maintain harmony."

Many of our order have gone out into the world in secret, in attempts to repair what has been broken, but alas, this appears to be impossible."

Sporkulous Forkspoon, 3rd Prophecy

Bathroom


It's midnight. There's blood everywhere because, hot diggety ding-dong damn, you just murdered someone with a plastic spork for trying to destroy the Universe. I mean, congratulations and all, but seriously, that's just...weird, man.The corpse of the man you most royally ensporked for trying to destroy the Universe with only his pinkie finger (he can do that, you know) is lying in front of you on the floor of the derelict, teal, horrible-smelling men's room. There's an entrance to the hallway of the abandoned community center that you're in to the South.




The murder weapon, the spork, is clutched in your trembling fist. Despite how much ass you kicked, you are slightly disturbed. You drop the spork on the floor of the bloody bathroom with a wet click in your disbelief as to how much ass you truly kicked.

=== spring.z8 (v8) ===




 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                           


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     There is nothing on this planet more pleasant         


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     than an outdoor bath in a 104 degree pool.            


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     Steam surrounds you in an ethereal massage.           


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     Tufa deposits line the steep walls behind you         


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     and brilliant green algae decorate the rock where     


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     the spring trickles in.                               


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     A few bubbles and a small current                     


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     rise from the depths...                               


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                           


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
S H E ' S   G O T   A   T H I N G   F O R   A   S P R I N G


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
            An Interactive Dip in a Hot Spring


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
             Brent VanFossen, (C) 1997 - 2008


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Fourth place winner, 1997 Interactive Fiction Competition


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  XYZZY Award winner for best Non-Player Character, 1997


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [Press "s" to Skip the intro, "a" to read About the game,


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                or any other key to begin.]




"This is it!" he says as he dodges the last pothole and brings the truck to a stop. After twenty miles of the worst washboard road the country has to offer, you're just happy to have arrived.

You place your sandaled feet on solid ground and take a deep breath. The smells of autumn are at once sweet and earthy and full of the aroma of moisture and living things. A cool breeze blows in your face, soft and gentle. What a nice change, what a welcome relief from the tension and hustle of all you've left behind this weekend. It's just you and your husband, as he promised over a month ago.

You look around. What passes for the road you just traveled ends abruptly here. Over the last hour, bad asphalt gave way to gravel, which gave way, in turn, to the rutted two-track you see beside you. Ahead, the ruts continue, but it'll be on foot if you're to go any further. The old beater truck stands here, engine off but still ticking from the trip. Your husband closes the driver's door and comes around the rear to join you.

"How's my pretty lady?" he asks as he wraps his arms around you and places a kiss on your cheek from behind. "Tired, huh? Come on. Let's get the stuff. We'll be able to relax better once the tent's up."

He takes the two packs from the back of the truck and helps you into yours, then leads the way through the brush to the north. You roll up on the balls of your feet and give your pack a nudge, then pull the waist strap tight. Without looking back, you follow.

That was last night, and you hiked a short trail to a campsite off in the woods. Together you set up the tent, fixed a quick dinner, and fell asleep in each other's arms...






You wake with a start, something's missing, and you notice the sleeping bag is empty beside you. On his pillow is a handwritten note, which you collect. He must have crawled out early, as the sky is only now beginning to lighten.

You dress quickly, slip out of the tent, and follow the trail to the east.






SHE'S GOT A THING FOR A SPRING

An Interactive Dip in a Hot Spring
Copyright (C) 1997-2008 Brent VanFossen. All rights reserved.

(First time players should type "about".)


Release 
4
 / Serial number 
0
8
0
2
0
7
 / Inform v
6
.
1
5
 Library 
6/8
 




Aspen Grove


You stand in the middle of a grove of aspen, which extends in all directions. Slender white trunks reach for the sky with long thin fingers, stroking the clouds that blow in the autumn breeze. Leaves of gold rattle as the winds shift, and here and there one floats to the ground to join others that crackle underfoot when you move. A narrow path disappears east into the trees, and a camping area is visible through a small opening to the west. North is a wide meadow.

"You," he always tells you, "are my pretty lady." You smile at the thought. He's always quick to tell you how he likes that smile, your easy laugh, your blue-green eyes that "sparkle" so. It's probably all just a little silly, but you like it nonetheless.


You are 
wearing 
some
 
shorts
, 
a 
shirt
 and 
a pair of
 
flipflops
.

Aspen Grove


You stand in the middle of a grove of aspen, which extends in all directions. Slender white trunks reach for the sky with long thin fingers, stroking the clouds that blow in the autumn breeze. === standing.z5 (v5) ===










Content warning: touches on themes of despair, anger, and hopelessness in the face of a terminal illness.

Type READER at any prompt to enable an accessible screen reader mode.










(Press 
any key to continue
.)


You've put this off too long.

The floppy was on the bureau when you got back home. Jeff must have left it before you drove him to the hospital for the last time. No label. Just your name, scrawled in pencil.

You suppose you owe it to his fans to find out what's on it. Maybe one last masterpiece. They'd like that.

The timestamps on the earliest files are decades old. You start with the first.
















LOADING FILE 
1
 of 6




(Press 
any key to continue
.)






You Are Lost In An Endless Desert!


A TrackYourPath Book by Jeffie Crestin (Room 309)




How To Read This Story (Page 1)


This is not just any book!!!
 To complete this story, you must think carefully and make decisions by TURNING TO the right page. (You can type TURN TO, T, or just a number!)

Sometimes you might be told to add a number to a page to know where to turn to. But be forwarned: it is HIGHLY DANGEROUS to turn to any page 
you have not been told
!!


To begin your adventure, TURN TO 110.





> 
          

          

          

          

          

          

          

          

You Are Standing
          

          

          

   

The pages start at 1.




> 
          

          

          

          

          

          

          

          

You Are Standing
          

          

          

   

The pages start at 1.




>
